logTitle: IELTS Reading Log: Forest management in Pennsylvania, USA

lexicalItems.sourceContext: Forest management in Pennsylvania, USA

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: The practical application of biological, physical, quantitative, managerial, economic, social, and policy principles to the regeneration, management, utilization, and conservation of forests to meet specified goals and objectives.

phase3Production.content: Effective forest management is crucial for balancing timber production and wildlife conservation.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: How managing low-quality wood (also known as low-use wood) for bioenergy can encourage sustainable forest management

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: Timber that is not suitable for high-value products like furniture or construction due to its size, shape, species, or condition.

phase3Production.content: New markets for bioenergy have created a demand for low-quality wood that was previously left to rot.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...for bioenergy can encourage sustainable forest management

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: Renewable energy produced from organic matter, such as wood, agricultural crops, or waste.

phase3Production.content: The power plant is converting to bioenergy, using wood chips instead of coal.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...can encourage sustainable forest management

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: The management of forests in a way that meets the needs of the present without compromising the ability of future generations to meet their own needs.

phase3Production.content: Sustainable forest management practices ensure the long-term health and productivity of our woodlands.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...and depends on the management goals for a given forest.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: The specific objectives that a landowner or manager aims to achieve for a particular area of forest.

phase3Production.content: The management goals for the park include increasing biodiversity and improving recreational access.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...but for a landowner more interested in wildlife habitat, the real value of that stem (or trunk) may be the food it provides to animals.

phase1Inference.contextualGuessVI: Môi trường sống của động vật hoang dã

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: The natural home or environment of an animal, plant, or other organism.
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Môi trường sống của động vật hoang dã

phase3Production.content: Leaving dead trees standing can provide crucial wildlife habitat for birds and insects.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: Likewise, if the tree suffers from black knot disease, its value for timber decreases...

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: A common fungal disease that affects certain trees, characterized by hard, black swellings on the branches.

phase3Production.content: The orchardist had to prune many branches affected by black knot disease to save the trees.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: In the past, Pennsylvania landowners were solely interested in the value of their trees as high-quality timber.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: To be interested only in one particular thing and nothing else.

phase3Production.content: He was solely interested in the profit margin and not the environmental impact of the project.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...the value of their trees as high-quality timber.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: Wood that is highly valued for its strength, appearance, and suitability for fine furniture, flooring, or construction.

phase3Production.content: Oak and walnut are examples of high-quality timber used by cabinet makers.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...and leave behind poorly formed trees that were not as well suited to the site where they grew.

phase1Inference.contextualGuessVI: Những cây có hình dáng xấu

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: Trees that have grown in a crooked, stunted, or otherwise undesirable shape.

phase3Production.content: The forester marked the poorly formed trees for removal to allow healthier ones to thrive.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: This practice, called ‘high-grading’, has left a legacy of ‘low-use wood’ in the forests.

phase1Inference.contextualGuessVI: Khai thác chọn lọc cây tốt

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: A type of logging in which only the best, most valuable trees are removed, often leaving a forest of lower quality and less genetic diversity.
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Khai thác chọn lọc cây tốt

phase3Production.content: Decades of high-grading have degraded the overall health of the forest ecosystem.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: This practice... has left a legacy of ‘low-use wood’ in the forests.

phase1Inference.contextualGuessVI: Đã để lại một di sản là

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: To have created a situation that continues to exist for a long time after it began.
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Để lại di sản/hệ quả là

phase3Production.content: The industrial revolution left a legacy of pollution that we are still dealing with today.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: These trees have lower economic value for traditional timber markets, compete for growth with higher-value trees, shade out desirable regeneration and decrease the health of a stand* leaving it more vulnerable to poor weather and disease.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: Existing or available in large quantities; plentiful.

phase3Production.content: This region is abundant in natural resources, including coal and iron ore.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...shade out desirable regeneration and decrease the health of a stand...

phase1Inference.contextualGuessVI: Che bóng sự tái sinh mong muốn

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: To block sunlight from reaching young, valuable trees, preventing them from growing.
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Che bóng sự tái sinh mong muốn

phase3Production.content: Invasive species can quickly shade out desirable regeneration of native plants.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...and decrease the health of a stand* leaving it more vulnerable to poor weather and disease.

phase1Inference.contextualGuessVI: Sức khỏe của một lâm phần (một khu cây)

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: The overall condition and vigor of a community of trees in a specific area.
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Sức khỏe của một lâm phần

phase3Production.content: Thinning the forest can improve the overall health of a stand by reducing competition for resources.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...leaving it more vulnerable to poor weather and disease.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: Exposed to the possibility of being attacked or harmed, either physically or emotionally.

phase3Production.content: Young seedlings are particularly vulnerable to drought and frost.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: Management that specifically targets low-use wood can help landowners manage these forest health issues, and wood energy markets help promote this.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: The sector of the economy concerned with buying and selling wood for use as a fuel source.

phase3Production.content: The growth of wood energy markets provides an economic incentive for sustainable forest thinning.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: Most wood used for energy in Pennsylvania is used to produce heat or electricity through combustion.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: By the process of burning something.

phase3Production.content: Internal combustion engines generate power through the combustion of fuel.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: Many schools and hospitals use wood boiler systems to heat and power their facilities...

phase1Inference.contextualGuessVI: Hệ thống lò hơi đốt gỗ

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: Heating units that burn wood to produce hot water or steam for heating buildings.
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Hệ thống lò hơi đốt gỗ

phase3Production.content: Modern wood boiler systems are highly efficient and produce very little smoke.

lexicalItems.targetLexeme: incorporate wood into their coal streams
lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...and some coal plants incorporate wood into their coal streams to produce electricity.

phase1Inference.contextualGuessVI: Kết hợp gỗ vào dòng than của họ

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: To mix wood chips or biomass with coal as fuel for power generation, a practice known as co-firing.
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Kết hợp gỗ vào dòng than của họ

phase3Production.content: Power companies are encouraged to incorporate wood into their coal streams to reduce carbon emissions.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: Wood can also be gasified for electrical generation and can even be made into liquid fuels like ethanol and gasoline for lorries and cars.

phase1Inference.contextualGuessVI: Được khí hóa để phát điện

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: Converted into a gas in order to be used as a fuel to generate electricity.
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Được khí hóa để phát điện

phase3Production.content: Biomass can be gasified for electrical generation, providing a cleaner alternative to direct combustion.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...and can even be made into liquid fuels like ethanol and gasoline for lorries and cars.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: Combustible substances in a liquid state, such as gasoline, diesel, or ethanol.

phase3Production.content: Researchers are developing new ways to produce liquid fuels from algae.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: Several tree- and plant-cutting approaches, which could greatly improve the long-term quality of a forest, focus strongly or solely on the use of wood for those markets.

phase1Inference.contextualGuessVI: Chất lượng lâu dài của một khu rừng

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: The overall health, diversity, and value of a forest over an extended period of time.
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Chất lượng lâu dài của một khu rừng

phase3Production.content: Selective cutting, rather than clear-cutting, is better for the long-term quality of a forest.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: One such approach is called a Timber Stand Improvement (TSI) Cut.

phase1Inference.contextualGuessVI: Khai thác Cải thiện Lâm phần

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: A cutting method where less desirable trees are removed to improve the health, growth, and quality of the remaining, more valuable trees.
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Khai thác Cải thiện Lâm phần

phase3Production.content: A Timber Stand Improvement Cut was prescribed to increase the growth rate of the oak trees.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: In a TSI Cut, really poor-quality tree and plant material is cut to allow more space, light, and other resources to the highest-valued stems that remain.

phase1Inference.contextualGuessVI: Những thân cây có giá trị cao nhất

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: The trees in a stand that have the greatest economic or ecological worth.
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Những thân cây có giá trị cao nhất

phase3Production.content: The goal of the thinning was to direct more resources to the highest-valued stems.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: Removing invasive plants might be another primary goal of a TSI Cut.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: The main or most important objective.

phase3Production.content: The primary goal of the rescue mission was to ensure everyone's safety.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: The stems that are left behind might then grow in size and develop more foliage and larger crowns or tops that produce more coverage for wildlife...

phase1Inference.contextualGuessVI: Phát triển nhiều tán lá hơn

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: To grow a greater mass of leaves.
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Phát triển nhiều tán lá hơn

phase3Production.content: After the rain, the plants began to develop more foliage.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...they have a better chance to regenerate in a less crowded environment.

phase1Inference.contextualGuessVI: Một môi trường ít đông đúc hơn

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: A setting with more space and less competition between individuals.
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Một môi trường ít đông đúc hơn

phase3Production.content: Seedlings grow faster in a less crowded environment with ample sunlight.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: TSI Cuts can be tailored to one farmer’s specific management goals for his or her land.

phase1Inference.contextualGuessVI: Được điều chỉnh cho phù hợp với

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: To be adapted or customized to suit a particular need or purpose.
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Được điều chỉnh cho phù hợp với

phase3Production.content: The educational program can be tailored to the specific needs of each student.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: Another approach that might yield a high amount of low-use wood is a Salvage Cut.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: To produce or provide a large quantity of something.

phase3Production.content: This new variety of corn is expected to yield a high amount of grain per acre.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: Another approach that might yield a high amount of low-use wood is a Salvage Cut.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: The harvesting of trees that have been damaged or killed by natural causes, such as fire, insects, disease, or wind.

noun.meaning: sự cứu hộ, sự tận thu

phase3Production.content: A Salvage Cut was conducted after the wildfire to recover some economic value from the burnt timber.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: With the many pests and pathogens visiting forests including hemlock woolly adelgid, Asian longhorned beetle, emerald ash borer, and gypsy moth, to name just a few...

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: Harmful insects or other animals, and microorganisms such as bacteria or viruses that can cause disease.

phase3Production.content: Quarantine measures are in place to prevent the spread of foreign pests and pathogens.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...including hemlock woolly adelgid, Asian longhorned beetle, emerald ash borer, and gypsy moth, to name just a few...

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: A highly destructive invasive beetle from Asia that feeds on and kills ash trees.

phase3Production.content: The emerald ash borer has killed millions of trees across North America.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...it is important to remember that those working in the forests can help ease these issues through cutting procedures.

phase1Inference.contextualGuessVI: Quy trình cắt, phương pháp khai thác

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: The established or official way of felling and processing trees.

phase3Production.content: Proper cutting procedures are essential to ensure worker safety and minimize environmental damage.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: These types of cut reduce the number of sick trees and seek to manage the future spread of a pest problem.

phase1Inference.contextualGuessVI: Sự lây lan của vấn đề sâu bệnh

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: The expansion of an infestation of harmful insects or animals over a wider area.
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Sự lây lan của vấn đề sâu bệnh

phase3Production.content: Early detection is key to managing the future spread of a pest problem in agriculture.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: They leave vigorous trees that have stayed healthy enough to survive the outbreak.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: Trees that are strong, healthy, and full of energy and growth.

phase3Production.content: The gardener selected the most vigorous trees from the nursery for planting.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...that have stayed healthy enough to survive the outbreak.

phase1Inference.contextualGuessVI: Sống sót qua đợt bùng phát

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: To continue to live or exist, especially in spite of a sudden occurrence of a disease or pest.
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Sống sót qua đợt bùng phát

phase3Production.content: Only the most resilient species were able to survive the outbreak of the deadly virus.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: A Shelterwood Cut, which only takes place in a mature forest that has already been thinned several times, involves removing all the mature trees when other seedlings have become established.

phase1Inference.contextualGuessVI: Khai thác rừng non (để cây con mọc)

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: A logging method where mature trees are removed in a series of cuts over time to allow a new generation of seedlings to become established in the partial shade of the remaining trees.

phase3Production.content: The forester used a Shelterwood Cut to encourage the natural regeneration of pine seedlings.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...which only takes place in a mature forest that has already been thinned several times...

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: A forest that has reached an advanced stage of development, with large, old trees.

phase3Production.content: A mature forest provides a complex habitat for a wide variety of species.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...involves removing all the mature trees when other seedlings have become established.

phase1Inference.contextualGuessVI: Các cây con đã mọc ổn định

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: When young trees grown from seed have started to grow successfully and are firmly rooted.
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Cây con đã được thiết lập

phase3Production.content: Once the new seedlings have become established, the protective shelters can be removed.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: This then allows the forester to decide which tree species are regenerated.

phase1Inference.contextualGuessVI: Loài cây nào được tái sinh

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: Which types of trees are grown again or renewed in the forest.
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Loài cây nào được tái sinh

phase3Production.content: After a fire, foresters carefully manage which tree species are regenerated to create a more resilient ecosystem.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: It can also be used to develop a two-tier forest so that there are two harvests and the money that comes in is spread out over a decade or more.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: A forest with two distinct layers of canopy, usually an upper layer of older trees and a lower layer of younger trees.

phase3Production.content: Managing for a two-tier forest can provide continuous income and improve wildlife habitat.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...the money that comes in is spread out over a decade or more.

phase1Inference.contextualGuessVI: Được dàn trải trong một thập kỷ

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: To be distributed or extended over a period of ten years.
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Được dàn trải trong một thập kỷ

phase3Production.content: The payments for the car are spread out over a five-year period.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: Thinnings and dense and dead wood removal for fire prevention also center on the production of low-use wood.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: The process of selectively removing trees, primarily to improve the growth rate or health of the remaining trees.

phase3Production.content: Thinnings from the pine plantation were sold to a local paper mill.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: Thinnings and dense and dead wood removal for fire prevention also center on the production of low-use wood.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: The process of clearing out dead trees and branches from a forest.

phase3Production.content: Dead wood removal is a key part of maintaining the park's safety and appearance.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: Thinnings and dense and dead wood removal for fire prevention also center on the production of low-use wood.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: The set of precautions that are taken to prevent or reduce the likelihood of a fire that may result in death, injury, or property damage.

phase3Production.content: Creating firebreaks is an important fire prevention strategy in forested areas.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: However, it is important to remember that some retention of what many would classify as low-use wood is very important.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: The action of continuing to have or hold something.

phase3Production.content: The retention of some dead trees is vital for the forest's ecosystem.

lexicalItems.targetLexeme: nutrients cycle back into the soil
lexicalItems.sourceContext: The tops of trees that have been cut down should be left on the site so that their nutrients cycle back into the soil.

phase1Inference.contextualGuessVI: Chất dinh dưỡng quay trở lại đất

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: When essential elements for growth decompose and return to the earth, enriching it.
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Chất dinh dưỡng quay vòng trở lại đất

phase3Production.content: When leaves fall and decompose, their nutrients cycle back into the soil.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: In addition, trees with many cavities are extremely important habitats for insect predators like woodpeckers, bats and small mammals.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: Trees that have hollow spaces in their trunks or branches, often used by wildlife for shelter or nesting.

phase3Production.content: The old oak tree, with its many cavities, is home to a family of squirrels.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...extremely important habitats for insect predators like woodpeckers, bats and small mammals.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: Animals that hunt and eat insects.

phase3Production.content: Ladybugs are valuable insect predators that help control aphid populations in gardens.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: They also help control problem insects and increase the health and resilience of the forest.

phase1Inference.contextualGuessVI: Kiểm soát côn trùng có hại

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: To manage and limit the population of insects that cause damage to plants or spread disease.
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Kiểm soát côn trùng có hại

phase3Production.content: Introducing natural predators is an effective way to control problem insects without using pesticides.

lexicalItems.targetLexeme: health and resilience of the forest
lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...and increase the health and resilience of the forest.

phase1Inference.contextualGuessVI: Sức khỏe và khả năng phục hồi của rừng

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: The ability of a forest ecosystem to maintain its functions and recover from disturbances like fire, disease, or logging.
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Sức khỏe và khả năng phục hồi của rừng

phase3Production.content: Biodiversity is key to improving the health and resilience of the forest against climate change.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: Finally, rare species of trees in a forest should also stay behind as they add to its structural diversity.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: Types of trees that are not common and are found in only a few places.

phase3Production.content: The botanical garden has a special section dedicated to preserving rare species of trees.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...as they add to its structural diversity.

phase1Inference.contextualGuessVI: Sự đa dạng về cấu trúc

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: The variety in the physical arrangement of a forest, including the different sizes and ages of trees, and the presence of dead wood and multiple canopy layers.

phase3Production.content: A forest with high structural diversity can support a wider range of wildlife.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: A tree’s ‘value’ depends on several factors including its species, size, form, condition, quality, function, and accessibility...

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: To be determined or influenced by something else.

phase3Production.content: The success of our picnic depends on the weather.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: The same tree can be valued very differently by each person who looks at it.
